data.title: 'Regret' maintains New Order's good name [April 25, 1993]
data.meta_description: Acrimony and legal backbiting undermine one of New Order's biggest hits, plus Orbital's second album
data.text:
Hey, welcome to This Week In The 90s where we tell stories about (or loosely connected to) songs that were in the UK charts exactly 30 years ago.

This week, we‚Äôre talking about‚Ä¶

Internal tensions almost rip New Order apart

More top 40 hits from this week in 1993

Album of the week: Orbital‚Äôs brown album

üé∂ Number One song in the UK Top 40 is the Five Live EP from George Michael and Queen, but let‚Äôs have a listen to this week‚Äôs Number 8‚Ä¶

New Order, ‚ÄôRegret‚Äô

I‚Äôve previously discussed the joys of being named Bernard, and I think we exhausted that subject last time. The only thing I want to add is this: people with dorky names like me have a deep, deep love for rock stars who share our name.

There aren‚Äôt many rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll Bernards, especially if you exlude people born before the war (apologies to Bernard Cribbins). You‚Äôve basically got Bernard Edwards, founding member of Chic, and ex-Suede guitarist Bernard Butler.

And then there is Bernard Sumner of New Order.

Sumner tends to appear a lot in these newsletters‚Äîhe popped up just last week when we talked about Sub Sub. His regular appearances are down to the fact that Sumner is a bit of a main character in music history, and a lot of threads find their way back to him eventually.

He‚Äôs also a guy who knows the importance of a good name.

Maybe I‚Äôve forgotten

Bernard Sumner has changed his legal name twice, yet he never ditched ‚ÄúBernard‚Äù in favour of something more rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll, such as‚Ä¶ well, literally any other name.

He was born Bernard Sumner, but his mother later remarried and the whole family took the stepdad‚Äôs name: Dicken. Which means he spent his teenage years with the name Bernard Dicken.

[Side note: when I was a kid, the most famous Bernard was golfer Bernhard Langer. ‚ÄúLanger‚Äù is local slang here for ‚Äúpenis‚Äù. A fun time for me!]

Bernard went to school in Salford, where he befriended Peter Hook, which is a proper rockstar name. Hook and Sumner started going to gigs together, which is how they ended up at perhaps the most famous gig in the history of British alternative music: The Sex Pistols at Manchester‚Äôs Free Trade Hall in 1976.

Everyone at the Pistols show went on to start a band or record label, and Hook and Sumner were no different. They invited local weirdo Ian Curtis to be their singer and named themselves Stiff Kittens.

‚ÄúStiff Kittens‚Äù is provocative and slightly gross‚Äîin other words, a typical punk band name. But the band weren‚Äôt trying to make typical punk music. Someone in the group realised that names shape your destiny, so they looked for something that better reflected their ambitions.

The name Warsaw came from an instrumental track on Bowie‚Äôs album Low. It‚Äôs a grim, moody, industrial piece‚Äîexactly the mood that Warsaw wanted to capture.

Bernard Sumner‚Äîstill legally known as Bernard Dicken‚Äîstarted using a stagename at this point, referring to himself as Bernard Albrecht. Bernard had misheard the name ‚ÄúBerthold Brecht‚Äù once, and he liked this mangled version enough to take it as his own.

Warsaw were also due for a name change. In 1978, they became Joy Division, a darkly ironic reference to Nazi atrocities. This new identity seemed to unleash something even more brutalist in the music.

Joy Division became a lightning rod for the hopelessness and despair of Generation X, but most of that energy was focused on the enigmatic Ian Curtis. Sumner, Hook and drummer Stephen Morris were background figures, creating these jagged sonic backgrounds for Curtis‚Äôs lyrics.

And then Ian Curtis killed himself.

Save it for another day

Joy Division became New Order, but not all at once.

They had always promised each other that Joy Division wouldn‚Äôt continue if one member left. Curtis‚Äôs death forced them to rebrand, but they were still playing Joy Division songs to a Joy Division audience. They chose not to labour the point, and the first few New Order records avoided mentioning the band‚Äôs new name entirely.

Being a Joy Division tribute band started to grate. Stephen Morris later said:

‚ÄúIn England, after Joy Division ceased it was like every band on the John Peel show sounded just like bloody Joy Division! It was great to inspire people to get together and make music but not to clone it. They should be trying to do something a bit different.‚Äù

The others seemed to realise that New Order would have to do something, well, new. In his autobiography, Bernard Sumner wrote:

‚ÄúOur music had become so incredibly dark and cold, we couldn‚Äôt really get any darker or colder. I remember quite clearly sitting in a club in New York one night, around three or four o‚Äôclock in the morning, and thinking how great it would be if we made music, electronic music, that could be played in one of these clubs.‚Äù

This led to the real New Order, a band that sounds nothing like Joy Division (except for Hook‚Äôs unmistakable basslines).

‚ÄòCeremony‚Äô, ‚ÄòTemptation‚Äô and ‚ÄòBlue Monday‚Äô all became massive hits and put some daylight between them and their gloom-rock past. The money from this success went into The Hacienda nightclub, which kickstarted the UK‚Äôs dance music revolution.

During all the popstar chaos of this time, Bernard Dicken legally changed his name back to Bernard Sumner. He‚Äôs very committed to the Bernard thing. I love that about him.

Look at me, I‚Äôm not you

‚ÄúLiterally, you‚Äôre at that point in the relationship where you hate each other‚Äôs stinking guts, and somebody says to you, ‚ÄòWould you go back together, you and him?‚Äô and you say, ‚ÄòI would rather die‚Äô.‚Äù

‚ÄîPeter Hook

By 1992, New Order were in a dire financial situation. The Hacienda was a money pit that had gobbled the profits from New Order‚Äôs only Number One hit, 1990‚Äôs ‚ÄòWorld In Motion‚Äô. Factory Records, the label that had put Joy Division on the map, was hanging by a thread. And the band had co-signed many of these debts, making them personally liable.

At this stage, their only valuable asset was the name New Order. New Order hadn‚Äôt released a record since 1989‚Äôs ‚ÄòTechnique‚Äô, but that had been a huge hit. A new LP could generate enough cash to steady the ship.

Just one small technicality. New Order had effectively broken up.

Sumner was doing Electronic with Johnny Marr. Peter Hook had his own band, Revenge. The other two were recording as The Other Two. On the rare occasions they saw each other, they tended to have blow-out arguments.

So, Republic is an album made practically at gunpoint, which isn‚Äôt an ideal situation. By the time it was finished, the band were barely speaking, and Sumner and Hook were ready to murder each other.

And the plan didn‚Äôt even work. Factory Records was gone before Republic was finished, and no amount of cash could save The Hacienda. Nevertheless, the album was a hit, with lead single ‚ÄòRegret‚Äô making the Top 5.

A few months later, New Order went on indefinite hiatus.

You were a complete stranger

New Order reunited in the 2000s and made two excellent albums, after which things turned really nasty. Peter Hook quit for good in 2006, and the band reformed without him in 2011.

Here‚Äôs where it gets complicated.

New Order used to handle their money via a limited company called Vitalturn Ltd. You can see their details on Companies House‚Äîall four members listed as directors, including Peter Hook. New Order‚Äôs revenues (from sales, publishing, merch, etc) go to Vitalturn Ltd, and Vitalturn distributes profits equally to the band members.

Vitalturn also own all of the names involved: Joy Division, New Order, and The Hacienda. If anyone wants to use these names, they need permission from Vitalturn‚Äôs directors.

When Hook went solo, he used these names in a way that seems to have pissed off the other three. I‚Äôm not sure how, exactly, although he was at one point selling Peter Hook Hacienda Bass Guitars made from the club‚Äôs old floorboards.

The other three could have slapped Hook with a Cease & Desist, but instead they did something bizarre and kind of shitty. They founded a new company called New Order Ltd.‚Äîwithout Peter Hook as a director. Then, they leased all of Vitalturn‚Äôs intellectual property to the new company. New Order could keep earning without paying anything to Hook.

Sound dodgy? It was! Hook took them to court, with his barrister arguing that:

‚ÄúIt was as though George Harrison and Ringo Starr had got together at George‚Äôs house one Friday night and had acted together to divest Paul McCartney of his shareholding in the Beatles, and didn‚Äôt tell Yoko about it either.‚Äù

The case was settled, so we don‚Äôt know exactly how things were restructured, but Hook got a lot of money which is usually an indication that you won.

Hook can‚Äôt call his band New Order, but he often points out that the other band aren‚Äôt New Order either. Strictly speaking, they‚Äôre a completely different band‚Äîthey just happen to be renting the New Order name from Vitalturn Ltd.

I would like a place I could call my own

Names are powerful and valuable things. Obviously, they have commercial value as brands‚ÄîNew Order are always going to sell more tickets than Peter Hook & The Light, even though both bands essentially play the same setlist.

But names can shape the way you see the world too. Stiff Kittens could never have recorded ‚ÄòLove Will Tear Us Apart‚Äô, just as Joy Division could never have recorded ‚ÄòBizarre Love Triangle‚Äô.

Maybe this is why Bernard Sumner never dropped the name Bernard. Perhaps he knows that when you find an identity that works, you need to hang onto it.

Thanks for reading! If you enjoyed this, subscribe to get next week‚Äôs issue:

Elsewhere in the charts

[Number One, New] George Michael & Queen, Five Live EP

One of the good/bad things about reliving the 90s in real-time is that you get a genuine sense of how long things lasted. Grunge, for example, was a relative flash in the pan, considering its cultural impact.

Whereas post-Freddie grief has now gone on so long that it‚Äôs starting to feel cynical. Mercury died 18 months ago, around the time ‚ÄòSmells Like Teen Spirit‚Äô appeared, and yet the tributes keep coming. It‚Äôs giving exploitation.

In some regions, this EP included George Michael doing a mash-up of ‚ÄòKiller‚Äô and ‚ÄòPapa Was A Rolling Stone‚Äô. It‚Äôs excellent, and probably should have been a standalone single.

[3 ‚Üë] Whitney Houston, ‚ÄòI Have Nothing‚Äô

The most X Factor-y Whitney song, and perhaps the most X Factor-y song in the world. Credit where it‚Äôs due‚Äînobody could belt ‚Äòem out quite like Whitney. The key change at the end sounds like a hurricane making landfall.

[21, New] SWV, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm So Into You‚Äô

Debut UK single from Sisters With Voices. The trio only managed one major hit outside on this side of the Atlantic (the ‚ÄòHuman Nature‚Äô remix of ‚ÄòRight Here‚Äô, which will appear later in 1993) but their first album was quite a big deal in the States.

[26, ‚Üì] Sting, ‚ÄòSeven Days‚Äô

[27, New] PJ Harvey, ‚Äò50ft Queenie‚Äô

The song that got Polly into the Top 40 and mildly roasting on Beavis & Butthead. They liked the song and did a predictable ‚Äò50ft Weenie‚Äô joke, but they also pointed out that she looks like Mallory from Family Ties, which is devastatingly accurate.

Anyway, Rid Of Me is an amazing record! Look out for a review soon!

Album of the Week

Orbital, Orbital aka Orbital 2 aka The Brown Album

What‚Äôs the difference between music and noise? The answer: patterns. Music is about juxtaposing sounds in a way that creates rhythmic patterns, which means that music isn‚Äôt sounds, but relationships between those sounds.

That‚Äôs quite nerdy, but it‚Äôs also something that Paul and Phil Hartnoll set out to demonstrate in the opening track of Orbital 2. Just to make it even nerdier, they perform their experiment with a clip from Star Trek: The Next Generation.

Here in 1993, the nature of music is a hot topic, especially when we‚Äôre talking about electronic music. There were people back then (and there still are now) who would argue that you can‚Äôt make music with computers, or if you did, it would have to be avant-garde Philip Glass-type stuff.

Dance music could never be art.

The Hartnoll brothers are an incredible live act, as anyone who‚Äôs seen them live will tell you. They‚Äôve also made some phenomenally sophisticated albums that challenged some fundamental ideas about what music can be.

Orbital 2 isn‚Äôt quite their masterpiece (In Sides is hard to beat) but it showcases their evolving sensibilities. Very modern dance music collides here with other influences, including prog and krautrock. Throughout, there‚Äôs also that same mathematical obsession with structure and form that drives much of Aphex Twin‚Äôs work.

What makes Orbital better than Aphex Twin, in my mind, is that they‚Äôre just a bit more human. Orbital 2 has some banger choons, like ‚ÄòRemind‚Äô, as well as moments of sublime beauty like ‚ÄòHalcyon & On & On‚Äô:

A great record from two consistently great artists. And they‚Äôre only just getting started‚Ä¶
